message.name: A70
message.say: Welcome Jordan! I am Cristina and this is

message.name: A71
message.say: ! I will be your instructor for todays activities!

message.name: A72
message.say: Today, we are going to look at advertisements that use nonliteral langwidge, We will follow the steps of the clarifying strategy to help us understand what the writer is saying!

message.name: A73
message.say: Alright

message.name: A74
message.say: and Jordan, let's look at the first add!

message.name: A75
message.say: That is all the time we have for this activity! You got all the way through!

message.name: A76
message.say: and Jordan, thank you so much for all your hard work!

message.name: A77
message.say: Just remember to think about your clarifying strategy whenever you run into a word or phrase that is difficult to understand. The words or phrase may be a piece of non literal language and you may need to use your strategy to figure out the meaning.

message.name: A78
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A79
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A80
message.say: The correct answer is, take one at night, be out like a light! This phrase does not make sense when you read it literally.

message.name: A81
message.say: Is there a comparison being made in the slogan, take one at night, be out like a light? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A82
message.say: There is, a comparison being made in this slogan! Similes are a type of nonliteral langwidge that make comparisons using, like, or, as. This phrase uses the word, like, so this is a simile!

message.name: A83
message.say: Why is the writer comparing the reader and a light? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A84
message.say: The writer is making this comparison to describe the effects of the pill to the reader.

message.name: A85
message.say: What is the intended meaning of, out like a light? Click the correct response.

message.name: A86
message.say: The intended meaning of this simile is, to fall asleep quickly.

message.name: A87
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct response.

message.name: A88
message.say: The correct replacement is, take one at night to fall asleep quickly! Now we will move on to the next advertisement.

message.name: A89
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A90
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A91
message.say: The correct answer is the third choice. Blind as a bat? We can fix that! This does not make sense when red literally.

message.name: A92
message.say: Is there a comparison being made in the slogan, blind as a bat, we can fix that? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A93
message.say: There is, a comparison being made in this slogan! Similes are a type of nonliteral langwidge that makes comparisons using, like, or, as.This phrase uses the word, as, so this is a simile!

message.name: A94
message.say: Why is the writer comparing the reader's eyesight and a bat's eyesight? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A95
message.say: The writer is making this comparison in order to describe the reader's eyesight.Many people think bats can see in the dark, however they do not see very well at all.

message.name: A96
message.say: What is the intended meaning of, blind as a bat? We can fix that!? Click the correct response.

message.name: A97
message.say: The intended meaning of this simile is to say that someone has bad eyesight, or someone can not see very well.

message.name: A98
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct response.

message.name: A99
message.say: The slogan that appropriately replaces the nonliteral langwidge is, have bad eyesight? We can sell you glasses!

message.name: A100
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A101
message.say: asdf

message.name: A102
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A103
message.say: The nonliteral langwidge used in this advertisement is, it will keep you on the ball! This phrase does not make sense when taken literally.

message.name: A104
message.say: Is there a comparison being made in the slogan, it will keep you on the ball!? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A105
message.say: In this slogan, there is no comparison being made. Idioms are a type of nonliteral langwidge that does not make comparisons. This means that this is an idiom!

message.name: A106
message.say: Why is the writer using this nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response below.

message.name: A107
message.say: The writer is using this idiom to describe the purpose of this book.

message.name: A108
message.say: What is the intended meaning of this idiom? Click the correct response.

message.name: A109
message.say: The intended meaning of this idiom is, to stay up to date on tasks.

message.name: A110
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response below.

message.name: A111
message.say: The appropriate replacement for this idiom is, this book will keep you on task!

message.name: A112
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A113
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A114
message.say: The part of this advertisement that uses nonliteral langwidge is, the ultimate couch potato remote control. Specifically, couch potato, is what we will be looking at. This does not really make sense when taken literally.

message.name: A115
message.say: Is there a comparison being made in the phrase, couch potato? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A116
message.say: In the phrase, couch potato, there is no comparison being made. Idioms are a type of nonliteral langwidge that does not make comparisons.That means that this is an idiom!

message.name: A117
message.say: Why is the writer using this nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response below.

message.name: A118
message.say: The writer is using this idiom to describe the benefits of buying the remote.

message.name: A119
message.say: What is the intended meaning of, couch potato? Please click the correct answer below.

message.name: A120
message.say: The intended meaning of, couch potato, is, to stay seated.

message.name: A121
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A122
message.say: The appropriate replacement is, you can stay seated while watching TV with this remote!

message.name: A123
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A124
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A125
message.say: The part of this advertisement that uses nonliteral langwidge is, on cloud nine day spa. We will specifically look at the phrase, on cloud nine. When red literally, this does not really make sense.

message.name: A126
message.say: Is a comparison being made in the phrase, on cloud nine? Please click yes or no.

message.name: A127
message.say: There is no comparison being made in the phrase, on cloud nine. Idioms do not make comparisons.This means that this phrase is an idiom!

message.name: A128
message.say: Why is the writer using this nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A129
message.say: The writer is using this idiom to describe the purpose of the spa.

message.name: A130
message.say: What is the intended meaning of this nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct response.

message.name: A131
message.say: The intended meaning of this idiom is, to feel good.

message.name: A132
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A133
message.say: The appropriate replacement is, this spa will make you feel good!

message.name: A134
message.say: Take a look at this advertisement. When you think you are ready, click on the image to view the first question,

message.name: A135
message.say: If you need to look at the image again, click on the advertisement to make it bigger. When you are ready, click the ex in the upper right hand corner to make the ad smaller and answer the question. Which part of this advertisement uses nonliteral langwidge? Click the correct answer.

message.name: A136
message.say: The part of this advertisement that uses nonliteral langwidge is, one sip and you're in heaven! When we read this literally, it does not make sense.

message.name: A137
message.say: Is there a comparison being made in the slogan, one sip and you're in heaven? Please click yes or no.

message.name: A138
message.say: There is, a comparison being made in this slogan! Metaphors are a type of nonliteral langwidge that makes comparisons without using, like, or, as.The comparison does not use, like, or, as, so this is a metaphor!

message.name: A139
message.say: Why is the writer comparing, a sip of tea, and, being in heaven? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A140
message.say: What is the intended meaning of, one sip and you're in heaven? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A141
message.say: The intended meaning of this metaphor is, to make you feel very happy and relaxed.

message.name: A142
message.say: Which of these is a good replacement for the nonliteral langwidge? Please click the correct response.

message.name: A143
message.say: The appropriate replacement is, this tea makes you feel very happy and relaxed.
